awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exploring the Role of Organics in Atmospheric Contact Nucleation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on the study of a mechanism for the formation of ice particles in mixed phase clouds in the atmosphere.  This mechanism, called contact nucleation, occurs when an ice nucleating particle collides with the surface of a supercooled cloud droplet.  The results of this research will improve the ability to model particles and clouds in the Earth's atmosphere.

The research will test the following hypotheses: (1) Organic particles can act as contact nuclei to promote efflorescence of mixed organic-inorganic aqueous droplets, and the effectiveness of the organic will depend on composition of the aqueous phase; temperature and relative humidity; and composition, oxidation, viscosity, morphology, and size of the contact nuclei; and (2) Organic particles can act as contact nuclei to promote ice nucleation, and the effectiveness of the organic will depend on composition of the aqueous phase; temperature; and composition, oxidation, viscosity, morphology, and size of the contact nuclei. The experiments will be conducted using two complementary levitation techniques that allow freely-floating droplets to undergo single collisions with well-defined contact nuclei: a long working distance optical trap and a dual stage electrodynamic balance.

These studies are expected to provide fundamental data on contact nucleation that currently are not available in the literature. This effort will lead to improved theoretical descriptions of heterogeneous nucleation and enable contact nucleation to be included in atmospheric models that predict the formation of ice particles in the atmosphere.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The phase state of atmospheric particles (for example, liquid, crystalline, or semi-solid) influences many key processes that impact climate and air quality, such as light scattering, chemical reactivity, and cloud formation. Despite the importance of particle phase, the conditions under which aerosol particles undergo phase transformations is not well understood. In the present work, we aimed to increase understanding of aerosol phase state by (1) characterizing the properties of mixed organic-inorganic aerosol, which are abundant in the atmosphere, and (2) studying the process of contact nucleation, where liquid particles can crystallize to a solid state by particle collisions. We further explored how the physical and chemical properties of aerosol influenced the process of contact nucleation.

The project led to successful outcomes for new instrument development, generation of fundamental knowledge, and educational resources. During the project, we developed a new method for characterizing the physical properties of organic and mixed organic-inorganic aerosol. While characterizing the properties of organic-inorganic aerosol particles, we observed that mixtures of certain inorganic ions and organic molecules cause organic-inorganic aerosol to exist in an amorphous solid state in a wider range of relative humidity (RH) conditions than previously considered. This was attributed to the ability for certain ions to cross-link organic species. 

Contact nucleation studies were performed using mixed organic-inorganic droplets with inorganic crystalline contact nuclei. We demonstrated that organic components that have low viscosity and phase separate do not inhibit contact nucleation at all, while highly-viscous organic components that remain homogeneously mixed can inhibit contact nucleation at low RH. This was a significant result because it demonstrated that contact nucleation is a process that can promote crystallization of mixed organic-inorganic aerosol.

We also studied the phase changes associated with model respiratory aerosol, which is another form of organic-inorganic atmospheric aerosol. We demonstrated that the organic content of respiratory aerosol had a large impact on the humidity-dependent phase state. We provided evidence that the organic components of respiratory aerosol might have an impact on the airborne survival of pathogens.

The project also enabled important training and education experiences for early career students. Six undergraduate students from a primarily-undergraduate institution were engaged on the project, and were included in collaborative work at a research intensive university. Elements of the project were incorporated into the undergraduate curriculum through a course-based research experience, impacting an additional 20+ students a year. Additionally, community outreach involved attending local elementary schools to demonstrate single-particle levitation and atmospheric-related topics.

Overall, by contributing understanding of organic-inorganic aerosol properties, this project increased understanding of the phase state of atmospheric aerosol particles. Ultimately, the combined knowledge of organic-inorganic aerosol properties and the influence on contact nucleation can help reduce uncertainty in climate and air quality models. Outside of atmospheric science, phase transitions and particle properties in microenvironments are of significant interest to a wide variety of disciplines from pharmacokinetics in living systems to spray drying encapsulation processes. Thus, the insight developed during this project may also find broader applications, for example, with spray drying applications.
